alright to roast the beet we're going to

or until it just starts to get tender
we still want it a little firm this is

should with a little bit of effort be

to put mine away I'm going to wrap it

you can totally do this part ahead if
you want to use it immediately that
works too but I did put mine away
and then the next day I took it out I
unwrapped it and before we roast it with

and I might as well use that foil to

to come off really easily and of course

only problem with that is I would have

is going to include a liberal

let's go ahead and lay in our slices of

distribute them evenly and then we're
going to crumble over about two ounces
of fresh goat cheese I got some
beautiful local California goat cheese
and we're going to crumble that over
into all the empty spaces and by the way
goat cheese and beets are such an
awesome combination you see them
together all the time on menus and
there's a reason for that it works so
well and then once we crumble over our
goat cheese all we're going to do is
season this up with a little bit of
freshly ground black pepper and a
healthy dose of kosher salt you know my
feelings on underseasoned vegetables I'm
not a big fan so give it a nice
sprinkling of salt and then that's going
to go in a preheated 400 degree oven for
15 minutes or until it looks like this
our beets are sizzling in that walnut
oil that cheese is heated through the
edges are browning a little bit they

while this is still warm we're going to

sweeter side I've even done this with
lemon juice very delicious so drizzle
over something in flavorful and acidic
and then we're going to top this with a
big handful of
roasted walnuts and that's really the
thing that brings that creamy cheese and
those earthy beats together adds that
texture so do not forget the roasted

thinking that looks great let's eat now
